sentence: Shares of South Korean tech giant Samsung SSNLF slipped over 4% Monday following the company's warning that 2016 may be a difficult year.

In a New Year's statement to employees, Samsung CEO Kwon Oh-hyun said that issues such as a weak global economy and increased competition in the company's core businesses could continue to slow growth.
Specifically, Kwon warned that financial risks in emerging companies will lead to dangerous uncertainty.
"The territories of industries are collapsing," Kwon said.
"We have to compete in a new way that we've never experienced in the past."

Kwon said that to avoid these issues, Samsung needs to shift its focus away from its hardware segment-which centers around mobile phones, televisions, and memory chips-and put an emphasis on software.
"The competition landscape is changing to software and platforms, so we need to build a new system and competence," said Kwon.
By shifting to a software focus, Samsung will hope to avoid a tough 2016 by doing what worked for tech companies in 2015.
In fact, the best tech performers in the last year were "MAGS," or Microsoft MSFT , Amazon AMZN , Google GOOGL , and Salesforce CRM .
All of these companies cashed in on cloud computing software technology.
Samsung's dependence on hardware and its ensuing struggles are mirrored by its main competitor, Apple AAPL .
Samsung and Apple hardware are both top of the line, but more and more competitors are entering the market at a lower price point.
In addition to shifting to software focus, Samsung can take a page out of Apple's 2016 game plan and look to ensure that it secures the customers it already has.
This means making sure that Samsung users continue to upgrade to the newest products, such as its flagship Galaxy S phone line, which is due for a new edition this year.
The warning from Samsung is clear: the company will struggle to grow by continuing to rely on its current core businesses.
Samsung needs a shakeup, and a shift to software could be the key, but it also needs to be careful not to lose its loyal customers along the way.
